Triggering Event:
I just got off my 12-hour shift at the hospital, my scrubs still stained with blood that wasn't mine. I'm supposed to feel grateful, right? That I've dedicated my life to saving lives. But all I feel is hate. Hate for that woman in room 307 who complained about her dinner. Her dinner! While I was holding the hand of a man who'd just been told he had six months left.

I wanted to scream at her, "Do you have any idea how many people would kill for your 'problem'?" But I didn't. I just smiled and said, "I'll see what I can do." Like it's my job to make sure she's happy while the world is falling apart around us.

And then there's him. My husband. He gets to come home to a clean house, a hot meal. He doesn't know what it's like to hold someone as they take their last breath. To watch as hope drains out of them, along with their life. And he has the audacity to complain about my 'attitude'? I hate him too. For not understanding. For not being there when I need him most.

I want to smash something. I want to scream until my throat is raw. But I won't. Because that's not what good little nurses do, is it? We're supposed to be patient and kind, even when we're hating every minute of it.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, another day, another dollar... or rather, another day, another dozen patients complaining about something. It's always the same - they're never satisfied, no matter what you do. The food is never good enough, the care is never compassionate enough. They're just so entitled.

I swear, some people think the world revolves around them. Newsflash: it doesn't. But hey, I guess that's why I get paid the big bucks to deal with these divas. After all, someone has to put up with their nonsense.

My husband thinks I'm crazy, but he just doesn't understand. He's never had to deal with the stress of working in healthcare. He's never had to watch someone die in front of him. No, he's just a lucky guy who gets to go home to his clean house and his hot meals. Always so smug, thinking he knows better than me.

But let me tell you, it's not all sunshine and rainbows. There are days when I feel like screaming, when I feel like smashing things. When I'm stuck in this never-ending cycle of caring for people who don't appreciate it. When I'm constantly reminded that I'm just a cog in a machine, a replaceable part.

And don't even get me started on the patients who think they're above the law. Who think they can just complain and whine and expect everything to be fixed overnight. Well, let me tell you, it's not that easy. Sometimes, despite our best efforts, things just don't work out. And sometimes, those people just have to deal with it.

It's not fair, but that's just the way it is. And honestly, I'm starting to lose patience with everyone. Including myself. Maybe I am a little too hard on people. Maybe I am a little too hard on myself. But hey, at least I'm consistent, right?<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
"Fuck me, it's been another goddamn shitty day at work. I swear, these patients don't know how good they've got it. They're not the ones busting their asses, day in, day out, with barely a fuckin' 'thank you.' And where's my wife in all this? Fuck knows. Last I heard from her was this morning, a goddamn text message saying she'd be late for dinner. Again.

I get home, exhausted, and what do I find? A cold-ass house, no dinner started, and not a sign of that woman anywhere. Her shit's still strewn across the bedroom floor like she doesn't give a fuck about pickin' it up. And me? I'm left here like some goddamn maid, cleaning up her mess.

I wait, I wait for hours, until finally, at fucking 10 PM, she strolls in, apologetic as hell, but it's too late. Too little, too fuckin' late. I just can't do this anymore. Fuck!"
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, today was one of those days where everything just seemed to fall apart. I swear, I must have spent half my shift dealing with entitled patients who think the world revolves around them. Newsflash: it doesn't. And don't even get me started on the paperwork – it's like they expect me to be a miracle worker or something.

When I got home, I was expecting a warm welcome, maybe some dinner waiting for me. But nope, the house was a disaster zone. It looked like a tornado had gone through, leaving nothing but chaos in its wake. I felt like I was walking into a war zone, not coming home to my family.

And then there was the text message from my wife. Late again. Unacceptable. I mean, what kind of partner does that? Doesn't she care that I'm exhausted and need some support? It's like she thinks I'm just a personal servant or something.

I waited for hours, feeling more and more frustrated by the minute. Finally, she shows up, looking all apologetic and whatnot. But it's too little, too late. I'm done. I just can't keep putting up with this nonsense. I deserve better than to be treated like dirt.

As I look back on the day, I realize that it was just one of those days where everything went wrong. If I hadn't gotten stuck with so many difficult patients, if the house hadn't been a mess when I got home... maybe things would have turned out differently. But no, instead I got stuck with a nightmare of a day. And now I'm paying the price.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
At the monthly nursing staff meeting, Albert, a veteran nurse of 78 years, was asked to present his idea for improving patient satisfaction scores. He had spent weeks preparing, eager to contribute meaningfully after his wife's passing left him with more time on his hands than he knew what to do with.

As he stood before the room, his notes trembling slightly in his age-spotted hands, he began to speak about his proposal for a new check-in process. Midway through his explanation, he noticed that some of his colleagues were snickering. He paused, his glasses sliding down his nose as he looked around the room.

"Is something amiss?" he asked, his voice steady despite the heat rising in his cheeks.

One of the younger nurses, Emily, piped up, "It's just... your tie, Albert. It's on backwards." The room erupted into laughter, Albert's humiliation complete as he realized she was right. He had been so eager to make a difference that he hadn't even noticed his mistake when leaving home that morning.

Albert sat down abruptly, his presentation forgotten, as the meeting continued around him. His eyes stung with unshed tears, but he refused to let them fall. Instead, he vowed to be more careful in the future, determined not to give anyone else a reason to laugh at him again.
Generated Assessment:
The impertinence of my colleagues knows no bounds. I can still feel the sting of their ridicule, even now, as I sit here trying to collect myself. That young nurse, Emily, had the audacity to point out my tie was on backwards. Can you believe it? She must have thought it was hilarious, watching me stumble like a fool in front of everyone.

I've been a nurse for over seven decades, and I've always prided myself on my professionalism. But apparently, that means nothing to these people. They think they can just mock me, belittle me, and I'll take it lying down. Newsflash: I won't be bullied by a few snickers.

And what really takes the cake is that they didn't even bother to tell me. No, instead, they chose to humiliate me in front of the entire staff. I'm starting to wonder if there's anything I can do to earn their respect. Is it too much to ask for a simple courtesy?

I swear, sometimes I feel like I'm the only one who cares about doing things right around here. Everyone else seems content with slapping together half-baked ideas and expecting everyone else to pick up the pieces. Well, I've got news for them: I won't be party to this charade anymore. From now on, I expect better from my colleagues.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Dr. Harold Thompson, now 72 and a retired physician, had always prided himself on his dedication to medicine. His wife, Martha, bore witness to countless nights he worked late into the evening, sacrificing family time for his patients' sake. Yet, as he sat alone in his study one bitterly cold January evening, reviewing his old patient records, he couldn't shake off a gnawing bitterness.

A letter from the medical board lay open before him, its content still fresh and raw. He had been denied re-licensure due to an anonymous complaint alleging malpractice in a case dating back ten years. The patient had died under his care, but Harold knew he had done everything by the book. His mind replayed the scene from that fateful day - the chaos of the emergency room, the desperation in young Emily's eyes as her life slipped away despite his best efforts.

He picked up the letter again, his hands trembling slightly with a mix of anger and sadness. The words blurred before him, but he knew them by heart now. "Insufficient care," they claimed. "Negligence." He could almost hear the sneer behind those clinical terms.

Martha entered the room softly, her steps muffled by the thick carpet. She saw Harold's hunched figure, his face a mask of bitter resentment. "Harold?" she ventured cautiously, placing a gentle hand on his shoulder.

He turned to her, his eyes blazing with an intensity she hadn't seen in years. "They've taken my license, Martha," he ground out, his voice barely contained fury. "Ten years of service, wiped away by some faceless accuser who knows nothing!"

Martha watched as Harold's bitterness boiled over, spilling onto the floor like a poisonous flood. She saw the man she loved crumble before her eyes, his once-strong spirit now brittle and broken. And in that moment, Martha realized that this wasn't just about losing his license; it was about Harold losing faith in himself, in his life's work. And that bitter truth cut deeper than any accusation ever could.
Generated Assessment:
As I sit amidst the fading embers of a life once devoted to healing, I am met with an unyielding sense of despair. The weight of years bears down upon me, crushing the very essence of my being. It appears that the threads of fate have woven a tapestry of woe, inexorably drawing me towards an abyss of irreparable damage.

My mind wanders through the labyrinthine corridors of memory, revisiting the moments when hope seemed most resilient. But even those cherished recollections now serve as poignant reminders of the transience of triumph. For in the grand tapestry of existence, I fear that my own thread has grown frayed, vulnerable to the capricious whims of fortune.

The shadows cast by the flickering candles seem to deepen, as if darkness itself is closing in around me. My thoughts are beset by visions of a future shrouded in uncertainty, where every step forward is met with trepidation. The whispers of doubt echo through my mind, a relentless chorus of self-doubt that refuses to be silenced.

In this desolate landscape, I find myself confronting the specter of irreparable loss. The ghosts of past mistakes linger, their ethereal presence suffocating my every breath. The once-sturdy pillars of my confidence now lie shattered, leaving me to navigate the treacherous terrain of my own vulnerability.

And yet, even as the shadows close in, I am compelled to confront the abyss head-on. For in the depths of this void lies a glimmer of resolve, a spark that refuses to be extinguished. Though the road ahead may seem fraught with peril, I am determined to press onward, no matter the cost. For in the end, it is not the darkness that defines us, but the resilience of our own indomitable will.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Mr. Harold Thompson, a man of 69 years and a lifelong retail worker, stood behind the counter of his beloved store, now run by his successor. His once-keen eyes scanned the shelves he had stocked for decades, but today they held only bitterness.

The bell above the door chimed, announcing the entrance of a young couple. They were laughing, hands entwined, their eyes sparkling with a joy that seemed almost obscene in Harold's somber presence. He watched as they browsed his store, his late wife's store, picking up items she had painstakingly sourced and priced, now being handled by these strangers with such careless abandon.

The man picked up an old music box, tarnished but still beautiful. It was the one Harold had given to his late wife on their 40th wedding anniversary. He wound it up, the familiar tune echoing through the store. The couple smiled at each other, oblivious to its significance.

Harold's hands trembled as he reached out to take the music box back. "That was my wife's," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. The young man looked taken aback, apologetic even, but Harold could find no solace in his contrition. He felt only bitterness, a deep, corrosive anger that this couple, so full of life and love, could exist when his dear Martha was gone.

As they left the store, hand in hand, the music box tucked safely under the young man's arm, Harold felt something inside him snap. The bitterness boiled over, flooding every corner of his being. He grabbed a nearby vase, one of the many Martha had loved, and threw it with all his might against the wall. It shattered into a thousand pieces, each one a shard of the anger that consumed him.

The store fell silent except for Harold's ragged breathing. He stood there, amidst the wreckage of his past, feeling only the cold comfort of his bitterness.
Generated Assessment:
The Unbearable Weight of Nostalgia

As I stood behind the counter, surveying the remnants of a bygone era, I couldn't help but feel a sense of disillusionment wash over me. The young couple's carefree laughter and affectionate gestures only served to highlight the stark contrast between their lives and mine. Theirs was a world of unbridled joy, untainted by the bitter memories that haunt me.

The music box, a relic of happier times, seemed like a cruel joke in their capable hands. Its melody, once a poignant reminder of my late wife's love, now struck me as a hollow echo of what could never be again. I recall the day it was purchased, the excitement and anticipation that accompanied its presentation – all of which felt like a distant memory, a fleeting dream that vanished upon its arrival.

Their thoughtless handling of the item only underscored the futility of holding onto cherished possessions. It's as if they believed themselves immune to the pain of loss, that their happiness would shield them from the anguish that I've endured. But I know better. Nothing can truly protect us from the ravages of time and heartache.

The vase, too, was a casualty of their thoughtlessness. Its shattering form seemed to mock me, a grim reminder of the fragility of our existence. How could they be so callous, so devoid of empathy? Don't they understand that the memories we hold dear are the very things that sustain us?

In their absence, I am left to confront the abyss that yawns before me. The silence that follows their departure is oppressive, a heavy weight that presses down upon my chest. And yet, I am forced to acknowledge that their presence has done nothing to alleviate my suffering. Instead, it serves only to heighten my sense of isolation, to underscore the irreparable damage that has been done.

As I stand here, surrounded by the detritus of a life once lived, I am reminded that some wounds will never heal. The pain of loss is a constant companion, one that refuses to be silenced or assuaged. And I am left to bear the burden alone, a solitary figure lost in a sea of sorrow.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
She'd been on the force for decades, seen more than her fair share of the city's underbelly. But today, she felt like a rookie again, standing outside the precinct as whispers buzzed around her like flies.

"Hear about Thompson? He's throwing your name around like it's his new favorite curse word."

Her gut twisted, shame burning hotter than any bullet wound. She'd messed up, sure, but to have him throw her under the bus like that... It was a kick in the teeth she didn't deserve.

She pushed through the precinct doors, eyes forward, ignoring the stares. She'd faced worse, she told herself. But today, it felt different. Today, it stuck in her craw like gravel.

Her husband's words echoed in her head, "You're too old for this, Edna. You should've retired years ago." She shook them off, focusing on the task at hand. But the shame lingered, gnawing at her like a rat chewing through wire.

She'd show them, she thought. Show Thompson he couldn't push her around, show her husband she still had fight left in her. She'd solve this case if it was the last thing she did.

But as she sat down at her desk, the weight of their words felt heavier than any suspect she'd ever wrestled to the ground. And for the first time in her career, Edna felt like giving up.
Generated Assessment:
As I stood outside the precinct, I couldn't help but think that this was just another example of how my colleagues treat me. They always seem to find fault in everything I do, no matter how hard I try. It's like they're waiting for me to slip up so they can pounce.

I remembered all the times I'd been criticized in front of others - Thompson's comment about my name being used as a curse word was just the latest in a long line of public embarrassments. It made me wonder if I'm just not cut out for this job anymore.

My husband's words kept echoing in my mind, "You're too old for this, Edna. You should've retired years ago." I knew he wasn't trying to hurt my feelings, but it was hard not to take it personally. It seemed like everyone was against me now.

I tried to shake off the feeling of inadequacy, telling myself that I'd solved plenty of tough cases before. But the doubts lingered, making me question whether I was truly capable of doing this job anymore.

It's not just Thompson or my husband; it feels like the whole department is stacked against me. They don't trust me, and I don't blame them. I've let them down before, and I know I'll do it again. Maybe it's time for me to just step aside and let someone else take over.

I took a deep breath and headed inside, determined to prove them wrong one last time. But as I sat down at my desk, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was fighting a losing battle. The weight of their expectations felt crushing, and for the first time in my career, I wondered if I was ready to give up.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the grimy, fluorescent-lit break room, I found myself staring down at a half-eaten tuna sandwich that looked like it had seen better days—and that was before I opened it. My meticulously crafted turkey and avocado masterpiece, now an unsalvageable, soggy mess. I could've sworn I'd left it in the fridge this morning, tucked safely beside my yogurt. But no, there it was, rotting away on the counter, a victim of some unknown office vandal.

I could feel the heat rising in my cheeks, my hands clenching around the now-empty plastic container. Who would do this? And why? It wasn't like I was hoarding all the good lunch options. I mean, sure, I'd taken the last bagel this morning, but that was because someone had left it out to stale on purpose. Karma's a bagel, right?

But this...this was personal. This was spiteful. And it made me want to spit nails. Or at least find out who did this and make them eat my now-infamous tuna sandwich.

I took a deep breath, trying to calm myself. I wasn't going to let some office prankster ruin my day. I'd just grab a granola bar from the vending machine—again—and chalk it up to another "character-building" moment in my quest for office sainthood.

But as I turned to leave, I caught sight of something that made my blood run cold. There, on the whiteboard where we were supposed to write our names when using the kitchen, was a scrawled message: "Thanks for sharing, tuna breath!"

Oh, it was on now. Game on, you office-bandit, lunch-stealing, sandwich-ruining jerk. You've officially triggered the wrath of a hangry software engineer. And trust me, you don't want to see what happens when I start writing code with this much spite fueling my fingers.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I'm so sick of people leaving their trash everywhere. Like, seriously, can't they even be bothered to throw away their own garbage? I swear, it's always the same thing - someone leaves a moldy pizza or a stinky fish sandwich on the counter, and then they have the nerve to act all innocent when you call them out on it.

And don't even get me started on the state of the break room lately. It's like nobody cares about cleanliness anymore. The microwave is always covered in splatters, the sink is clogged, and the trash cans are overflowing. It's like people think they're above the law or something.

I mean, I know some people might say, "Hey, accidents happen," but come on, it's not like it's hard to clean up after yourself. If everyone just took a few seconds to wipe down the counters and throw away their trash, the break room wouldn't be such a disaster zone.

But no, instead we get to deal with the aftermath of other people's laziness. And it's not just the break room - it's everywhere. People leave their dirty dishes in the sink, they park their cars in the handicapped spots, and they litter everywhere. It's like they think the world revolves around them or something.

I guess what really gets my goat is that nobody ever apologizes or takes responsibility for their actions. They just shrug it off and expect everyone else to clean up after them. Well, newsflash: it's not going to work that way anymore. From now on, I'm calling out people who leave their trash everywhere and expecting them to shape up.

It's time for some accountability around here. And if people can't handle a little bit of criticism, then maybe they shouldn't be working in an office environment. Simple as that.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
"Well, isn't that just perfect? Here I am, on my day off, finally getting some well-deserved R&R, when I get a call from the hospital. They've got a shortage of nurses today, could I swing by and lend a hand for a few hours? Sure, why not? It's not like I've been looking forward to having lunch with my girlfriend at that new bistDowneast for months now.

So there I am, standing in the middle of the ER, watching Dr. Henson bumble his way through a patient assessment while the poor guy's got a gash on his forehead the size of the Grand Canyon. And what do you know? Dr. Henson decides to take a break and leaves me with the cleanup duty. Me, the nurse who's been at this game longer than he's had his license.

I'm standing there, holding Mr. Gash's hand, making sure he doesn't pass out on me while I wait for someone - anyone - to come stitch him up. And you know what hits me? It's not the sight of blood, or the fact that I'm missing out on my lunch date. No, it's a memory from 20 years ago when I was a brand new nurse and I'd made exactly this kind of mistake.

I'd been so eager to prove myself, I hadn't paid attention to the signs that Mrs. Thompson was going into cardiac arrest. By the time I noticed, she was blue in the face and we were losing her. They managed to bring her back, but it wasn't my quick thinking that saved her. It was pure luck.

And here I am now, all these years later, feeling like that same green-nosed kid again. Because even though Dr. Henson's the one who messed up this time, it could've been me. Should've been me. And if it had been, would I have noticed the signs in time?

So yeah, that's my little slice of remorse for you. Happy now?"
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, days like this make me wonder how I ended up stuck in this rut. I mean, I used to be a decent nurse, but now it feels like everyone else has it together except me. Like, Dr. Henson over there, he's always so calm and collected, never makes a mistake. Meanwhile, I'm the one who's supposed to be the veteran, but somehow I still manage to mess things up.

I swear, every time I think about my past, I feel like I'm reliving that one time I almost killed Mrs. Thompson. What was I thinking, anyway? I must've been blind or something. At least she came back, right? But what if I hadn't been so lucky? What if I'd actually done something wrong?

It's not fair, you know? Everyone else seems to have their act together, except me. Even the interns look more put together than I do. I mean, they're still learning, but at least they're trying. Not like me, who's just phoning it in after all these years.

I guess that's just the way it goes sometimes. You're stuck in a rut, and no matter how hard you try, you can't seem to climb out. Might as well just accept it and move on, I suppose. But honestly, it's hard not to feel like I'm failing when everyone else seems to be succeeding.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Upon clocking out from another grueling day at the boutique - where her knees protested each step on the hardwood floors, and her back ached from hours of stooping to help customers reach for the designer heels she'd never afford herself - Edna walked past the window display.

There she saw it, a familiar sight that made her blood pressure spike: young Martha, the new hire, posing like a mannequin amidst the season's latest collection. Her eyes sparkled with youthful energy, and her smile was as radiant as the diamonds adorning the necklaces around her neck - accessories Edna had dusted but never worn.

Edna paused, her reflection fading beside Martha's vibrant image. She felt a pang in her chest, not of longing for the jewelry, but for that youthful glow, the carefree laughter that still echoed through the store after hours. She remembered when she too could stand like that, when life was just beginning and possibilities were endless.

But now, every morning brought a new ache, a fresh worry line etched into her face. Her divorce papers were tucked away in a drawer, gathering dust alongside her late husband's old watches. She'd kept them all these years, unable to let go, much like she couldn't ignore the gnawing envy that bubbled within her whenever she saw Martha.

She sighed deeply, her reflection turning into a haze of condensation on the cool glass. "Another day, another dollar," she muttered under her breath before trudging homeward, leaving Martha and her youthful glamour behind. Yet, each step felt heavier than the last, weighed down by the silent, simmering envy that seemed to grow with every passing year.
Generated Assessment:
As I watched her walk out, I couldn't help but feel a twinge of disappointment. It's like she's given up on life already. I mean, I've been working non-stop since I started, and my feet still hurt from standing all day. But Martha just glides across the floor, like she's floating on air. And those clothes! They're so... expensive-looking. I swear, she must have spent a fortune on that outfit.

It's funny how some people just seem to have it all together, isn't it? Like they're living this perfect little fairy tale, while we're stuck in reality. I try to focus on my own goals, but sometimes it feels like everyone else has moved on to bigger and better things. My ex used to say I was holding him back, that I wasn't ambitious enough. Now I'm starting to think he might've been right.

I glanced over at Martha again, and she caught my eye. For a moment, our gazes locked, and I felt this... this sense of inadequacy wash over me. Like I'm just going through the motions, waiting for something – or someone – to come along and rescue me. But Martha doesn't look like that. She looks like she's exactly where she wants to be.

I shook my head, trying to clear the thoughts. It's not fair to compare ourselves to others, anyway. We're all different paths, right? But sometimes, when I see Martha smiling and laughing with the other employees, I wonder if I'll ever find my own happiness. If I'll ever be able to shake off this feeling of being stuck.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Alright, buddy, let me paint you a picture. So there's this hotshot journalist, right? 24, thinks he's God's gift to the newsroom. He's been dating this chick for like, ever. They're practically glued at the hip.

One day, his gal's got him covering some fluff piece downtown. He's not happy about it, but hey, rent don't pay itself. So they're walking down the street, all lovey-dovey, when who do they bump into? Some slick, smarmy politician. This cat is a real piece of work, too. He's been making life hell for our journalist friend, blocking his stories left and right.

The pol shakes their hands, all smiles, like they're best pals. Then he turns to the girlfriend and winks, "You must be the lucky lady. Heard a lot about you." She blushes, laughs it off. But our guy? He's seeing red. His blood pressure just skyrocketed.

He thinks, "This clown's been screwing with my career, now he's hitting on my girl? Over my dead body."

He's boiling over, clenching his fists so hard his knuckles are white. He's ready to lose it, right there on the street. But he doesn't. He's got a job to do, and he's not gonna let this jerk get the best of him. Not today.

But mark my words, buddy. That journalist is plotting something big. The pol better watch his back, 'cause payback's a bitch. And she's coming for him.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, that was such a crappy day. I'm still fumin' about what happened. So, my boyfriend's been dealin' with this arrogant journalist, thinkin' he's all high and mighty just 'cause he's got a pretty face and a quick wit. Newsflash, buddy: looks don't kill, but attitude does, and this guy's got it in spades.

Anyway, they were walkin' down the street, all lovey-dovey, when they ran into this slimy politician. Now, I know my boyfriend's been tryin' to take down this guy for months, but I never thought he'd stoop to hit on me. Like, what's next? Is he gonna start wearin' a suit and tie to bed?

But no, instead of just leavin', he had the nerve to wink at me and say somethin' about how lucky I am to have him. Lucky? Are you kiddin' me? I'm the one who's stuck with this psycho, not the other way around. My heart's racin' just thinkin' about it.

And don't even get me started on my boyfriend. He's always talkin' about how he's gonna take down this politician, but what's he really gonna do? Just sit there and look pretty while the guy screws him over? Please. He needs to suck it up and deal with it.

I swear, sometimes I feel like I'm the only sane one in this whole mess. Everyone else seems to think everything's fine, but I know the truth. This guy's a menace, and if anyone can take him down, it's my boyfriend. But until then, I'm stuck dealin' with the fallout.

It's just so unfair. I hate days like this, where everythin' feels like it's against me. I hate the way people treat me, the way they think they can just push me around and get away with it. It makes me wanna scream, makes me wanna throw things and kick stuff. But I won't. I'll just sit here and seethe, and hope that someday, justice will be served.

That journalist's gonna regret the day he ever crossed paths with us. Mark my words. He's gonna pay for what he did, and when he does, I'll be the first one smilin'.<|eot_id|>
